ext_description.p: An Assembly_module_interface_terminal is a type of . An Assembly_module_interface_terminal is the terminal accessed by an external application. The Assembly_module_interface_terminal is not supported by all systems but is there for structural integrity in a multi-level hierarchy.

ext_descriptions.ext_description:
An Assembly_module_terminal is a type of . An Assembly_module_terminal may be an
or additionally may be a . An Assembly_module_terminal may be associated with an instance of
to specify a connector level interface definition for an assembly. This association is maintained in the usage view.
The Assembly_module_terminal supports multi-level design, analysis, and verification in a multi-discipline environment. Explicit description of Assembly_module_terminals allows connectivity requirements to be explicitly stated and interference requirements to be identified early in the design and development cycle. The availability of explicit connector data provides the ability to more easily distinguish terminals that are physically part of different connectors, as well as letting the connector location transform locate all terminals for that connector.
If there is a connector associated with the terminal, then the terminal is actually a terminal of that connector and not separate from that connector.

ext_description.p:
specifies the role of the
for the Assembly_module_terminal. There may be more than one
for an Assembly_module_terminal. The value of this attribute need not be specified. If the data is available in the source system, it shall be supplied.
ext_description.note:
The specified by the terminal or mounting feature may be the same
that is specified by the associated . In this case the whole terminal is the .

ext_descriptions.ext_description:
specifies the role of the
for the Assembly_module_terminal. When a related_connector is supplied, the location of the terminal shall be determined by the location of the related_connector and the location of the reference_terminal in that connector. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

specifies the role of the
for the Assembly_module_terminal. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

specifies the role of the
for the Assembly_module_terminal.
If the related_connector exists then associated_definition shall be the assembly for the related_connector.
If the related_connector exists then for that connector shall exist.
If the related_connector does not exist, then the reached via the path SELF\.. shall be the reached via the path SELF\..
If a related_connector is specified, the position, shape, and orientation of the Assembly_module_terminal shall be overriden by the reference_terminal position, shape, and orientation.
A related_connector shall be specified if and only if the reference_terminal is specified.

ext_description.p: An Assembly_module_usage_view is a type of . An Assembly_module_usage_view may be a . An Assembly_module_usage_view provides additional domain knowledge for the design organization.
ext_description.note: The Assembly_module_usage_view supports intellectual property protection. A design organization can control the amount of data they provide to a licensee or purchaser by including only a specifically tailored set of data in a usage view.

Shape information is provided by
or by .

In order to exchange exact connector data as part of the usage view, members of may be populated to explicitly relate a connector definition to the usage view. Note that the connector view included may just be that required to satisfy the interface definition requirements and may not be the same connector view that exists in the design department archive for internal design purposes. WR1 inherited from constrains the members of Assembly_module_usage_view for this purpose.
ext_description.example: This data can include the information currently included in an interface control drawing (ICD). Other data included in an ICD might be members of .

Figure 1 illustrates that the information in an Assembly_module_usage_view can be different from the information in a design view. The information in this illustration is sufficient to analyse airflow characteristics and interference characteristics, as well as information related to the connectors in the design.

ext_descriptions.ext_description:
specifies an inverse relationship that specifies that the existence of the Assembly_module_usage_view is dependent on the existence of the
that specifies the Assembly_module_usage_view as its . There shall be zero or more Assembly_module_terminals for an Assembly_module_usage_view.

specifies the role of the
for the Assembly_module_usage_view.
The function implemented shall be the function whose terminals are mapped to the terminals of this assembly module usage view.

A Layered_assembly_module_terminal is a type of
that is part of the interface between the and its next higher assembly.

specifies the role of the
for the Layered_assembly_module_terminal.

ext_description.p: A Layered_assembly_module_usage_view is a type of . A Layered_assembly_module_usage_view provides the information needed to include the in the design of the next higher level assembly, but not necessarily sufficient information to reproduce that .
ext_description.note:
A
may be located in a usage view in addition to terminals.
ext_description.example: Figure 2 illustrates details available in a usage view for a . The information available in the usage view specifically is separate from that in the design view and the relationships between the two views are usually controlled by a design organization.

ext_description.p:
specifies the largest
in the negative direction from an externally defined datum. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
ext_description.example: An example of the maximum_negative_component_height attribute is for a printed circuit assembly with through-hole components, where the maximum lead protrusion dimension is given. That dimension is the maximum_negative_component_height. Another example of the maximum_negative_component_height attribute is for a printed circuit assembly with surface mounted components on both sides. The maximum_negative_component_height attribute is for the distance between the established datum and the maximum material condition of the vertical dimension of the highest surface mount component on the secondary side of the printed circuit assembly.

ext_description.p:
specifies the largest
in the positive direction from an externally defined datum. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
ext_description.example: An example of the maximum_positive_component_height attribute is for a printed circuit assembly where the maximum component height in the positive direction relative to a datum is given. This dimension pertains to the fit of the printed circuit assembly in its next assembly. That dimension is the maximum_positive_component_height.

ext_descriptions.ext_description: The orientation vector direction shall be considered to be positive when it is parallel to the normal of the top side of the interconnect substrate instance.
The direction from the for the shall be negative in the Z axis direction.
The direction from the for the shall be positive in the Z axis direction.
